title: 105_s526
content: Increase in excise taxes on tobacco products to fund the Child Health Insurance and Lower Deficit Act. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase excise taxes on cigarettes and cigars. For cigarettes, the tax per thousand is raised to $33.50 from $12, and for cigars, it is raised to $3.141 from $1.125 per thousand. Additionally, the tax on cigars is set at 35.59% of the selling price, not exceeding $83.75 per thousand. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase excise taxes on cigarette papers, cigarette tubes, smokeless tobacco, and pipe tobacco. The tax rates are adjusted to 2.09 cents for cigarette papers, 4.18 cents for cigarette tubes, $6.09 for smokeless tobacco, and $2.41 for chewing tobacco. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase excise taxes on tobacco products. The tax rates for pipe tobacco are adjusted to $1.88. The amendments apply to articles removed after September 30, 1997. A floor stocks tax is imposed on tobacco products and cigarette papers held for sale before October 1, 1997. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase excise taxes on tobacco products. The tax rates for pipe tobacco are adjusted to $1.88. No tax shall be imposed on cigarettes held in vending machines on October 1, 1997. Each person is allowed a $500 credit against the taxes imposed on October 1, 1997. On October 1, 1997, a tax was imposed on cigarettes, and anyone holding cigarettes on that date is liable for the tax. The tax must be paid by January 1, 1998, in the manner prescribed by the Secretary. Articles in foreign trade zones are also subject to the tax. Articles in foreign trade zones on October 1, 1997, are subject to the tax if internal revenue taxes have been determined or customs duties liquidated before that date. Definitions for terms used in this subsection align with those in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Treasury or their delegate. Rules similar to section 5061(e)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code apply to controlled groups. All provisions of law applicable to taxes under section 5701 also apply to floor stocks taxes, with the Secretary able to designate the ultimate taxpayer. The person who may receive a credit or refund under the tax provisions is ultimately responsible for the tax imposed.
